body:
Well, that did not take long.

A day after Fox News announced that its Republican presidential primary debate in August would include only the 10 candidates polling the highest in national surveys, Rick Santorum denounced the criteria on Thursday.

“In January of 2012, I was at 4 percent in the national polls, and I won the Iowa caucuses,” said Mr. Santorum, the former senator from Pennsylvania, who is now near the bottom of most national surveys. “I don’t know if I was last in the polls, but I was pretty close to last.”

Recalling well-funded candidates who flamed out from campaigns past, Mr. Santorum, talking with reporters after his address at a Republican conference in Oklahoma City, mocked a national polling standard.

“The idea that a national poll has any relationship to the viability of a candidate — ask Rudy Giuliani that, ask Phil Gramm that,” he said, citing spectacular failures from the 2008 and 1996 Republican races. “You can go on down the list of folks who were doing real well in national polls and didn’t win a single state and were not a viable candidate.”
description: The former Pennsylvania senator’s comments came after Fox News said its Republican presidential primary debate would include only the 10 candidates polling highest in national surveys.
title: First Draft: Rick Santorum Denounces Fox News Curbs on Debate
